entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French clos-, stem of clore, from Latin claudere to shut, close; perhaps akin to Greek kleiein to close clavicle

def.dt: :to move so as to bar passage through something close the gate
:to block against entry or passage close a street
:to deny access to the city closed the beach
:screen exclude close a view
:to suspend or stop the operations of close school often used with down
:enclose contain
:to bring to an end or period close an account
:to conclude discussion or negotiation about the question is closed
:to consummate by performing something previously agreed close a transfer of real estate title
:to terminate access to (a computer file or program)
:to bring or bind together the parts or edges of a closed book
:to fill up (as an opening)
:to make complete by circling or enveloping or by making continuous close a circuit
:to reduce to nil closed the distance to the lead racer
:to contract, fold, swing, or slide so as to leave no opening the door closed quietly
:to cease operation the factory closed down the stores close at 9 p.m.
:to draw near the ship was closing with the island
:to engage in a struggle at close quarters :grapple close with the enemy
:to come together :meet
:to draw the free foot up to the supporting foot in dancing
:to enter into or complete an agreement close on a deal
:to come to an end or period the services closed with a short prayer
:to reduce a gap closed to within two points
:to refuse admission the nation closed its doors to immigrants
:to go out of business
:to ignore deliberately
:to unite in a concerted stand especially to meet a challenge
:to be uncompromisingly obstructive closed the door to further negotiation

entry.pt: close end conclude finish complete terminate mean to bring or come to a stopping point or limit. close usually implies that something has been in some way open as well as unfinished close a debate. end conveys a strong sense of finality ended his life. conclude may imply a formal closing (as of a meeting) the service concluded with a blessing. finish may stress completion of a final step in a process after it is painted, the house will be finished. complete implies the removal of all deficiencies or a successful finishing of what has been undertaken the resolving of this last issue completes the agreement. terminate implies the setting of a limit in time or space your employment terminates after three months.

def.dt: :a coming or bringing to a conclusion at the close of the party
:a conclusion or end in time or existence :cessation the decade drew to a close
:the concluding passage (as of a speech or play)
:the conclusion of a musical strain or period :cadence
:a hostile encounter
:the movement of the free foot in dancing toward or into contact with the supporting foot

entry.et: Middle English clos, literally, enclosure, from Anglo-French clos, from Latin clausum, from neuter of clausus, past participle

def.dt: :an enclosed area
:the precinct of a cathedral
:a narrow passage leading from a street to a court and the houses within or to the common stairway of tenements
:a road closed at one end

entry.et: Middle English clos, from Anglo-French, from Latin clausus, past participle of claudere

def.dt: :having no openings :closed
:confined or carefully guarded close arrest
:high 13
:formed with the tongue in a higher position than for the other vowel of a pair
:restricted to a privileged class
:secluded secret
:secretive she could tell us something if she would … but she was as close as wax A. Conan Doyle
:strict rigorous keep close watch
:hot and stuffy a room with an uncomfortably close atmosphere
:not generous in giving or spending :tight
:having little space between items or units a close weave a close grain
:fitting tightly or exactly a close fit
:very short or near to the surface a close haircut
:being near in time, space, effect, or degree at close range close to my birthday close to the speed of sound
:intimate familiar close friends
:very precise and attentive to details a close reading a close study
:marked by fidelity to an original a close copy of an old master
:terse compact
:decided or won by a narrow margin a close baseball game
:difficult to obtain money is close
:characterized by liberal use especially of commas
:within one's personal interests so that one is strongly affected the speaker's remarks hit close to home
:within a sensitive or personal area the criticism cut close to the bone
:in a reserved or cautious manner
:in a close position or manner
Chuck 1940– Charles Thomas Close Am. painter
:a narrow escape
:a corporation whose stock is not publicly traded but held by a few persons (as those in management)
:clipped short close–cropped hair
:having the hair clipped short a close–cropped actor
:having a compacted smooth texture
:having narrow annual rings or small wood elements
